questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a demographic process?
questions.explanation:
Morbidity is not a demographic process. Demography refers to the study of the population. Demographic processes include: • Fertility • Mortality • Marriage • Migration • Social mobility These processes continuously bring about changes in the population size, composition, and 
distribution.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question: Question 2: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the death rate start declining?
questions.explanation: The death rate starts declining in stage 2 or the early expanding phase of the demographic cycle.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question: Question 3: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the birth rate start declining?
questions.explanation:
The birth rate starts declining in stage 3 or the late expanding phase of the demographic cycle. India is currently in this stage of the demographic cycle. The year 1921 is called the year of the great divide in India. This is because, since 1921, the 
absolute number of people getting added to the population during each decade has been on the 
rise. This is the year in which India moved from stage 1 to stage 2 of the demographic cycle.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question:
Question 4: A group of demographers studied the changes in the birth and death rates of two countries, A 
and B from the year 2001 to 2011. The collected data is given below. In which stages of the 
demographic cycle are countries A and B in respectively?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, country A is in stage 2 and country B is in stage 4 of the demographic cycle. 423 
Sold by @itachibot According to the given data, in country A, the high birth rate has remained unchanged with a 
decline in the death rate. This will result in an exponential increase in the population. This means 
country A is in the early expanding stage of the demographic cycle. In country B, the low birth rate and death rates have remained unchanged. Thus, the population 
will attain a plateau phase and remain stationary. This means country B is in the low stationary 
stage of the demographic cycle.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements is true regarding the fifth stage of the demographic cycle?

options.d: Birth rate falls below death rate

questions.explanation:
In stage 5 of the demographic cycle, the birth rate falls below the death rate. In this stage, the death rate attains a low stable rate while the birth rate keeps declining. Thus, the 
curve of the birth rate will cross the curve of the death rate in a graph of the demographic cycle 
and falls further below. The demographic gap is negative and the population is declining. So, this stage is known as the 
declining stage.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question:
Question 6: While studying the birth and death rates of a country, a demographer found it to be in the 
early expanding stage of the demographic cycle. Which of the following findings would lead 
him to such a conclusion?

options.a: Increased birth rate and decreased death rates
options.c: Decreased birth rate and increased death rates
options.d: Unchanged birth rate and decreased death rates

questions.explanation:
Early expanding stage (stage 2) of the demographic cycle is characterized by an unchanged birth 
rate and decreasing death rate.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question:
Question 7: A researcher is studying the demographic cycle of various countries. In which stages of the 
cycle will she notice an increase and a decrease in the demographic gap respectively?
questions.explanation:
The demographic gap starts increasing in stage 2 and starts decreasing in stage 3. The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rate and death rate which develops 
when a country undergoes a demographic transition. In stage 2 of the demographic cycle, the death rate declines but the birth rate remains unchanged. 
Hence, the demographic gap increases and reaches a maximum by the end of stage 2. In stage 3, 
both the death rate and birth rate are declining so the demographic gap starts decreasing.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the stage of demographic cycle marked 
by the red arrow?
questions.explanation:
424 
Sold by @itachibot The marked stage is the late expanding phase (stage 3) of the demographic cycle. A 
demographic gift or demographic dividend is seen in this stage. This refers to the presence of a higher number of economically productive individuals (young and 
middle-aged adults) in the population due to a higher birth rate in the previous demographic 
phase (phase 2). India is currently experiencing the demographic gift. The birth rate starts declining alongside a death rate that continues to fall in stage 3 causing a 
decline in the demographic gap. The death rate declines further and the birth rate falls in this 
stage.

questions.question:
Question 10: In which stage of the demographic cycle will the phenomenon of a demographic trap be 
maximally seen?
questions.explanation:
The phenomenon of a demographic trap is seen maximally in the early expanding stage (stage 2). This phenomenon refers to a period in which there is high fertility and birth rate and a declining 
death rate. The population grows exponentially in this stage and this growing population exceeds 
the national or regional carrying capacity. Countries in this stage are said to be caught in 
a demographic trap.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question:
Question 11: While conducting a field study in a village, you found the birth and death rates of the 
population to be 42 and 31 respectively. What is the current annual growth rate of this 
population?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the current annual growth rate is 1.1%. Here, the birth rate is 42 i.e 42 live births per 1000 population, and the death rate is 31 i.e 31 
deaths per 1000 population. Current annual growth rate = crude birth rate – crude death rate. So, current annual growth rate = 
42-31= 11 per 1000 population or 1.1%.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question: Question 13: What was the population of India, as of 2021?
questions.explanation: The population of India, as of 2021, was around 1.39 billion. This is as per UN 2021 data.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question: Question 14: According to the 2021 UN data, what is India's population growth rate?
questions.explanation:
According to UN data, India's population growth rate in 2021 was 1%. As per the last published SRS data of the Indian government, it was 1.2% in 2018. India's population is currently increasing at a rate of 16 million each year. It currently falls in the 
rapidly growing phase of population growth.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question:
Question 15: You have been tasked with studying the age and sex structure of a population with high rates 
of female infanticide. Which of the following methods will you prefer to use?
questions.explanation:
The age and sex structure of a population may be best represented using a population pyramid. It is a histogram that shows the distribution of ages across a population. It is divided down the 
center between male and female members of the population.
questions.chapter_heading: Demography I  Demographic Cycle  Annual Growth

questions.question: Question 16: What does the age pyramid of India look like?
questions.explanation:
The age pyramid of India is broad at the base and narrow at the top. This is typical of most 
developing nations. 426
